thread.section_title: Media & Entertainment - Crain's New York Business News Feed
thread.title: Tweeters react to Condé Nast's acquisition of indie music reviews site Pitchfork
thread.title_full: Tweeters react to Condé Nast's acquisition of indie music reviews site Pitchfork

author: Matthew Flamm
title: Tweeters react to Condé Nast's acquisition of indie music reviews site Pitchfork
text:
— The Scatenato (@TheScatenato) October 13, 2015 
Never in my life imagined tweeting the words "Conde Nast now owns Pitchfork". #relevant #influential — e.j. friedman (@loudersoft) October 13, 2015 
“It brings a very passionate audience of millennial males into our roster.” Ugh. You deserve each other. http://t.co/0XL00Bs59b — JOHN BRISSENDEN (@johnbrissenden) October 13, 2015 
In an interview, Condé Nast Chief Digital Officer Fred Santarpia described the site as a natural fit. 
"Whether Pitchfork is talking about music or anything else, their commitment to editorial excellence is a natural fit with the DNA of Condé Nast," he said. He added that its video content and music festivals in Chicago and Paris were also a good fit for the publisher, which, like all magazine companies, has been investing in new revenue streams. 
Condé Nast will also help increase distribution for Pitchfork's quarterly print magazine Pitchfork Review . 
Though he was quoted by the New York Times saying that the site would give Condé Nast access to "millennial males" —a remark that also drew comment on Twitter—Santarpia insisted that it would bring millennials of both genders. 
In an interview with Variety , Pitchfork founder and CEO Ryan Schreiber said the deal would allow the site to maintain "the creative independence that we've always had."
